dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, uh, what a wild couple of days, right? I mean, Monday was brutal, but Tuesday just kept that momentum going, didn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, uh, what a wild couple of days, right? I mean, Monday was brutal, but Tuesday just kept that momentum going, didn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Like, we saw major losses again. The Dow dropped another 879 points, S&P 500 down 3%, Nasdaq 2.8%. Just, uh, red across the board.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Like, we saw major losses again. The Dow dropped another eight hundred seventy nine points, S and P five hundred down three percent, Nasdaq two point eight percent. Just, uh, red across the board.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow dropped 879 points, or 3.1%, while the S&P 500 lost 3% and the Nasdaq Composite lost 2.8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's all because of, you know, these growing fears around the coronavirus, right? Investors just fleeing risky assets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's all because of, you know, these growing fears around the coronavirus, right? Investors just fleeing risky assets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After Mondays 1000-point drop, major stock market losses continued on Tuesday as fears over the spread of the coronavirus intensified and investors fled risky assets in favor of safer ones, like bonds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They're just, like, piling into safer options. Bonds, for example. We saw 10-year U.S. Treasury yields hit a record low on Tuesday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They're just, like, piling into safer options. Bonds, for example. We saw ten-year U.S. Treasury yields hit a record low on Tuesday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: investors fled risky assets in favor of safer ones, like bonds. The Dow dropped 879 points, or 3.1%, while the S&P 500 lost 3% and the Nasdaq Composite lost 2.8%. 10-year U.S. Treasury yields hit a record low on Tuesday

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, correct me if I'm wrong, but the yield curve, which is a pretty big recession indicator, actually inverted on Monday? That's, uh, that's not great.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, correct me if I'm wrong, but the yield curve, which is a pretty big recession indicator, actually inverted on Monday? That's, uh, that's not great.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 10-year U.S. Treasury yields hit a record low on Tuesday after the yield curvea measure of the difference between 3-month and 10-year bond yields that is widely used as a recession indicatorinverted on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. It's a pretty classic sign that, you know, economists really pay attention to. It suggests trouble ahead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all. It's a pretty classic sign that, you know, economists really pay attention to. It suggests trouble ahead.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I thought there was, like, a brief glimmer of hope overnight though? Futures rallied a bit?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I thought there was, like, a brief glimmer of hope overnight though? Futures rallied a bit?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. futures had rallied slightly overnight following Mondays losses, seemingly pointing to a Tuesday rebound, but stocks largely remained in the red during the day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, a tiny rebound that just, poof, evaporated. Stocks were pretty much in the red all day long.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a tiny rebound that just, poof, evaporated. Stocks were pretty much in the red all day long.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. futures had rallied slightly overnight following Mondays losses, seemingly pointing to a Tuesday rebound, but stocks largely remained in the red during the day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And then the CDC comes out, basically saying, "Hey, this is likely to be a global pandemic."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then the C D C comes out, basically saying, Hey, this is likely to be a global pandemic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The CDC said on Tuesday that the coronavirus is expected to cause a global pandemic, and the U.S. has now begun its first test of an experimental drug to treat the disease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, doesn't exactly instill confidence, you know? But then you have Larry Kudlow, from the National Economic Council, saying it's contained and not an economic tragedy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, doesn't exactly instill confidence, you know? But then you have Larry Kudlow, from the National Economic Council, saying it's contained and not an economic tragedy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: National Economic Council director Larry Kudlow had a more optimistic view, telling CNBCs Kelly Evans that the coronavirus has been contained in the United States and that the outbreak is not likely to be an economic tragedy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, that's a pretty different take than, uh, say, Nouriel Roubini â€“ Dr. Doom himself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, that's a pretty different take than, uh, say, Nouriel Roubini - Doctor Doom himself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally different. Roubini, who called the '08 crisis, he's saying it's gonna be *more* severe than expected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally different. Roubini, who called the eight crisis, he's saying it's gonna be more severe than expected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The epidemic is likely to be more severe than currently expected...the economist Nouriel Roubini, best known for his analysis of the 2008 financial crisis, wrote in Financial News.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he's warning about, like, huge disruptions to the Chinese economy, spillover effects on global supply chains, even pharma inputs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he's warning about, like, huge disruptions to the Chinese economy, spillover effects on global supply chains, even pharma inputs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the disruption to the Chinese economy will have spillover effects on global supply chains including pharma inputs, of which China is a critical supplier and business confidence, all of which will likely be more severe than financial markets current complacency suggests

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which China is, uh, a critical supplier for. So, like, what's the takeaway for everyday investors? Panic or...?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which China is, uh, a critical supplier for. So, like, what's the takeaway for everyday investors? Panic or...?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: pharma inputs, of which China is a critical supplier

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, Forbes cited experts who said, "Don't panic yet." And that classic advice: investors typically "buy the dip" after big drops.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, Forbes cited experts who said, Don't panic yet. And that classic advice: investors typically buy the dip after big drops.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even with these major losses, experts say you shouldnt panic yet. One silver lining? Investors typically buy the dip following big drops.

dialogue_turns.text: Right, the old "buy the dip." We'll see if that, uh, you know, holds true this time around. It's a tricky situation.
